item.title: Contact
item.description: Email: moshepol[at]mit[dot]edu Twitter LinkedIn Fun Fact: Some words are regular travelers, going on vacation abroad and returning with a new accent. Consider the Arabic dār al-ṣināʿa (literally, house of manufacture; a factory). It was borrowed into Latin around the middle of the previous millenium as arsana, eventually becoming the word we know in English as arsenal. Not quite a place of production, but a place for storage of weapons (“arsenal, n.

item.title: Moshe Poliak
item.description: I am a PhD student in Brain and Cognitive Sciences at MIT. I study psycholinguistics, or what processes in the mind are involed in language production and comprehension. Specifically, I study how we use non-lexical properties of language in comprehension and production. Using the noisy channel framework, I investigate how expectations about the formof the utterance affects how we interpret it. I am also trying to figure out what exactly makes two utterances similar to each other, in speech and in writing, and how this depends on individual differences in linguistic background.
